misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles instead of five integers
misconceptions.description: The program reads only three double values (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers as required, so it cannot satisfy the problem specification of processing 5 integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can solve the task by reading three numerical inputs (v0, v1, t) as doubles, regardless of the requirement to read 5 integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must use Scanner to read exactly five integer values (e.g., with nextInt()) from the user, because the problem explicitly asks for 5 integers.
symptoms: Uses nextDouble instead of nextInt
Only three inputs are read
Prompt text does not mention 5 integers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely reusing code from a different problem (average acceleration) and not aligning input handling with the current specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change the input reading to use nextInt() and read five separate integers from the user instead of three doubles.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: All input handling clearly corresponds to a different three-parameter physics problem rather than reading five integers.

evidence.note: Reads three double values with a prompt for v0, v1, and t instead of five integers.

misconceptions.name: No loop used to handle multiple inputs
misconceptions.description: The code does not use any loop to process multiple inputs; it reads a fixed set of three values individually, which does not scale to processing a list of five numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is sufficient to read each value individually without a loop, even when the problem implies repeated similar processing.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When the problem specifies processing several similar inputs (like 5 integers), a loop (for or while) should typically be used to read and process each value.
symptoms: No for or while loop present
Each input is read by a separate nextDouble call
misconceptions.root_cause: Not recognizing the need for iteration when dealing with multiple similar operations or reusing a single-case example that does not use loops.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce a for loop that iterates 5 times to read each integer and process it (e.g., check evenness and update the sum).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code has no loop constructs at all and reads a fixed, small number of values, inconsistent with processing 5 numbers.

evidence.note: Inputs are read individually without any loop; there is no loop anywhere in the program.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number check
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether any input value is even (no use of n % 2 == 0 or any similar condition), so it cannot filter and sum only even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: They appear to believe that solving a different numerical formula (average acceleration) is sufficient and do not implement the required even-number filtering.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, the program must test each input value with a condition like if (n % 2 == 0) before adding it to the sum.
symptoms: No modulus (%) operator used
No if-statement related to even/odd checking
Computation is unrelated to parity
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely focusing on a different formula-based task and not translating the requirement of 'even numbers' into a conditional expression.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Within the loop that reads the 5 integers, add an if (n % 2 == 0) check and only then add n to the running sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditional logic involving %, so it cannot be performing the required even-number filtering.

evidence.snippet:
double a=(v1-v0)/t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+a);
evidence.note: Computation and output are for average acceleration; there is no if statement or use of % to check evenness.

misconceptions.name: No accumulator for sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The program computes a single formula a = (v1 - v0) / t and prints it as 'The average acceleration', instead of maintaining a running sum of even inputs and printing 'Sum of even numbers'.
misconceptions.student_belief: They believe that computing and printing the average acceleration value solves the problem, rather than accumulating a sum of selected inputs.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: An accumulator variable (e.g., int sum = 0) should be used, updated inside the loop when an even number is found, and finally printed with the correct message.
symptoms: No variable initialized to store a sum of inputs
The output message refers to average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
Only one arithmetic expression unrelated to summing a collection of numbers is used
misconceptions.root_cause: Using code from a kinematics example instead of implementing an accumulator pattern appropriate for this problem.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an int sum = 0 before the loop, add each even number to sum, and at the end print "Sum of even numbers: " + sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The only arithmetic in the program is the average acceleration formula, and there is no sum variable or appropriate output message.

evidence.snippet:
double a=(v1-v0)/t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+a);
evidence.note: Uses a single computed value 'a' and prints an average acceleration message; no sum variable or correct output label.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Problem Implementation: Solving a Different Problem
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating average acceleration (a = (v1-v0)/t), instead of the required problem (Sum of Even Numbers). The code reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers, and performs a division/subtraction calculation instead of loop-based summation and conditional checks.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes they are implementing the required program, but they appear to have copied or written code for a completely different task (Average Acceleration calculation) and submitted it for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The correct program must initialize a sum variable, use a loop to read and process five integers, check if each integer is even (n % 2 == 0), and accumulate the sum of only the even integers.
symptoms: Code reads 3 variables instead of 5
Code reads doubles instead of integers
Calculation is (v1-v0)/t instead of a summation loop
The printed output is 'The average acceleration is ...' instead of 'Sum of even numbers: ...'
misconceptions.root_cause: Major confusion regarding the assigned task, possibly by submitting the wrong file or having a complete misunderstanding of the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment title and description. You need to write a new program to calculate and display the sum of five *even* numbers entered by the user.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly implements the calculation for kinematic average acceleration, which is completely unrelated to the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem statement and rubric.

evidence.note: The code asks for 'v0, v1, and t' and reads 3 doubles, not 5 integers, indicating a completely different problem is being solved.

evidence.snippet:

System.out.println("The average acceleration is "+a);
evidence.note: The calculation and output specifically confirm the calculation of average acceleration, which does not address the required sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Data Type Usage (Double instead of Integer)
misconceptions.description: The problem requires reading 5 integers, but the student's code uses 'double' for input variables (v0, v1, t) and uses 'input.nextDouble()'. Although this is symptomatic of solving the wrong problem, it is also a fundamental data type error given the prompt's requirement for integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student used the double data type to store numerical input, despite the requirement for integer input.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Integers should be read using `input.nextInt()` and stored in variables of type `int`.
symptoms: Use of 'nextDouble()' and 'double' variables
misconceptions.root_cause: Mismatch between required input type (int) and implemented input type (double).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Remember to use 'int' variables and 'input.nextInt()' when the prompt specifies integer input.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem explicitly asks for integers, but the code explicitly uses doubles.

evidence.note: All input variables are declared as 'double' and read using 'nextDouble()'.

misconceptions.name: Complete Task Mismatch - Wrong Problem Solved

This indicates either a copy-paste error, submission of wrong file, or fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving a physics problem about acceleration, not the even number sum problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The assignment requires reading 5 integers, filtering for even numbers (using n % 2 == 0), and printing their sum.

Code calculates acceleration formula (v1-v0)/t instead of summing even numbers
No loop structure to process multiple inputs
No conditional logic to check for even numbers
Output is acceleration value, not sum of evens
misconceptions.root_cause: Complete submission error - wrong problem entirely submitted, or severe misunderstanding of assignment requirements
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Verify the assignment requirements. The code must: (1) read 5 integers in a loop, (2) check each number for even-ness using % operator, (3) accumulate sum of only even numbers, (4) print the result.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Absolute certainty - the submitted code solves a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) with no overlap with the required problem (sum of even numbers). This is not a minor logic error but a fundamental mismatch.

evidence.note: This entire code block solves a physics acceleration problem, not the even number sum problem. It reads 3 doubles and calculates acceleration, completely unrelated to the assignment.

misconceptions.name: Program implements a different problem (average acceleration) instead of summing even numbers

misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe the task is to compute the average acceleration given initial velocity v0, final velocity v1, and time t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly five integers from the user, check which of them are even (using n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of those even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt text refers to 'v0, v1, and t' instead of five integers
Only three input values are read instead of five
Inputs are stored as doubles instead of integers
No loop or conditional logic related to even numbers is present
Output message is about average acceleration, not sum of even numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely misreading or confusing this problem with a different physics-style exercise about acceleration.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and redesign the program: declare an int sum initialized to 0, use a loop to read 5 integers, for each number check if it is even with n % 2 == 0, add even numbers to sum, and finally print the sum with the required message.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output) is aligned with an acceleration problem and not with summing even numbers; no elements of the required solution are present.

evidence.note: The prompt, variable names, number and type of inputs, and the printed result all correspond to computing average acceleration, not reading 5 integers and summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: No loop structure for repeated input
misconceptions.description: Student did not implement any loop (for/while) to read multiple inputs. Instead, hardcoded three sequential read statements.
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading multiple values one-by-one without a loop is an acceptable approach
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When a problem requires reading a fixed number of inputs (5 integers), use a for loop to iterate 5 times and read each value. This is more scalable and demonstrates proper loop usage.
symptoms: Only 3 input reads instead of 5
No for or while loop in code
Hardcoded variable names instead of array or loop-based approach
misconceptions.root_cause: May lack understanding of how loops simplify repeated operations; possibly trying to solve the problem without proper algorithmic thinking
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Implement a for loop: 'for(int i=0; i<5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); }' to read all 5 integers efficiently.

evidence.note: Three sequential input reads without any loop structure; hardcoded instead of using iteration
